Graphical abstract During hydrotreating, silica poisoning of catalysts represents a severe problem, because the silicone compounds that are present in coker naphtha feedstocks are adsorbed and transformed on the alumina surface, deactivating it. To provide a solution, in the present work, silica was selectively removed from an industrial Ni-Mo/Al2O3 spent catalyst by applying a depolymerization process with glycerol that resulted in the restoration of silicon retention capacity, hydrodesulfurization and hydrodenitrogenation activities and physical properties of the catalyst. Catalyst samples, before and after the removal of silica compounds, were studied by nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR), N2 physisorption, diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS), atomic absorption spectroscopy and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Keywords Silica poisoning Hydrotreating catalyst Coker naphtha Removal of silicon compounds Reactivation 1 Introduction One of the most widespread catalyst poisons encountered in hydrotreated feedstocks is silicon. Silicone oil, used as antifoaming agent added to the heavy residue fed to coker drums, is considered as one of the main silica sources in downstream hydrotreaters. This compound (polydimethylsiloxane, PDMS) is cracked in the coking process to lighter molecular weight fragments consisting of siloxane groups. Since these species present boiling points ranging from 132 to 246 °C, a high percentage of these compounds ends up in the coker naphtha fraction. During hydrotreating (HDT) of this fraction, the silica fragments undergo a condensation reaction on the catalyst alumina surface. Silicon compounds are gradually deposited on the surface of HDT catalysts, made of alumina supporting metals such as cobalt or nickel and molybdenum, which lose activity progressively due to the blockage of pores and consequently of active sites [1,2]. These catalysts have relatively short lifetimes because of the accumulation of silicon species on the surface [3]. In these units, the rate of silicon deposition on the catalyst is usually what determines the cycle length rather than coke deactivation. Moreover, a premature deactivation involves a replacement of the catalyst with sever financial consequences. Once silica is bound to the alumina surface, it cannot be removed and until now is considered as a permanent poison [1,4, 5]. The impact is worse for other alumina-based catalysts, which are used in processes downstream from the hydrotreater like isomerization or reforming units due to the use of noble metals. In previous studies, the deactivation caused by silicon compounds deposition was investigated on NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst used as silicon traps. It was found that the silicon adsorption reaction rate is controlled by the transformation of D into T silicon species and the silicon compounds were retained on the alumina surface modifying the physical properties and activity for hydrotreating reaction of the catalyst [6,7]. At the end of HDT cycle, the catalysts used as silicon traps cannot be reused or regenerated and have to be send to final disposal. It is known that acidic or basic chemical reactions for dissolving silica from an industrial spent catalyst are expensive and the source of undesired pollution. In addition, they dissolve the active centers of cobalt, molybdenum and nickel. Thus, other types of reactions have to be found in order to avoid these problems while preserving the active sites of the catalyst to be reused. A paper describing for the first time the depolymerization of large surface area silicates was published in 2005 [8]. The main observations were reported as follows: in glycerol, near 200 °C, the silicate networks of mesoporous materials, silicates and zeolites with large specific surface areas underwent a deep depolymerization process. In a few hours, depending on the initial concentration of the solid in glycerol and on the temperature, amorphous gels were obtained. In these gels, a fraction of the initial SiOSi bonds was transformed into SiOC. A model accounting for the main remarks may be summarized. Consider a silicate made of n fragments. Each fragment contains OH groups liable to react with glycerol forming a methoxyl group: The reaction proceeds through the opening of siloxane bridges [9,10] with the methoxyl groups being linked to the silicate lattice. A temperature increase will displace the equilibrium of the etherification reaction and increase the number of methoxylated fragments, where water is expelled if the reaction temperature is higher than 100 °C. The connection of each fragment with the lattice is strongly weakened, and the freedom to move independently from one another is limited only by the aggregation forces and not by a formal SiOSi bond. Because of the paramount importance of silanols in the depolymerization reaction, the OH surface concentration in the precursor plays an important role. Kellberg et al. [11] investigated the nature of the Si present on deactivated catalysts by solid-state 29Si and 13C cross-polarization/magic-angle-spinning (CP/MAS) NMR spectroscopy. A detailed characterization of the deposited silicon species was done. The identified silicon species were mainly bulk SiO2, carrying surface species such as SiOH, Si(OH)2, SiCH3, =SiOHCH3 and =Si(CH3)2. So far, no study has been reported on the removal of silicon compounds deposited on a commercial catalyst with the aim that these catalysts can be reused. The treatments proposed until now modify either the alumina and/or active metals as well. The goal of the present work is to lay a firm scientific basis to show that it is possible to remove selectively silicon compounds from the surface of the HDT catalysts by applying the depolymerization process. Moreover, this study also highlighted that removal allows the recovery of the physical properties, capacity to trap the silica compounds and catalytic activity on hydrodenitrogenation and hydrodesulfuration reactions. A new technique aimed at regenerating these catalysts is presented. Samples of spent NiMo/Al2O3 HDT commercial catalysts were treated with glycerol. Physicochemical analyses were performed to follow the restoration impact on the catalyst properties. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Samples of an industrially spent NiMo/Al2O3 HDT commercial catalyst from coker naphtha unit were obtained from an industrial unit operating at 280−320 °C and 58 kg/cm2. The spent catalyst had a surface area of 140 m2/g, pore volume of 0.26 cm3/g and 8.8 wt.% of silicon. A refinery coker naphtha sample (4662 wppm of sulfur, 21.3 wppm of nitrogen and 14 wppm of silicon) was used to evaluate the activity of the reactivated catalyst. 2.2 Catalytic reactions 2.2.1 Silica removal The silicon compound removal (depolymerization) reaction was studied in a fixed-bed down flow micro-reactor at 260 °C and 25 kg/cm2 in order to remove silicon compounds from the catalyst surface. The reactor was packed with 140 g of spent catalyst, which was dehydrated in N2 stream at 150 °C for 2 h, and then a glycerol (Gly) stream was put in contact at different times. Samples were identified by considering the treatment time, for example, Re-2 h means that the sample was treated for 2 h with glycerol. The catalysts were washed with methanol and treated as such (i.e. in their commercial shape and size). 2.2.2 Catalytic activity The catalyst activity was measured in a continuous hydroprocessing unit equipped with a high pressure fixed-bed down flow micro-reactor at 260 °C and 55 kg/cm2. The reactor was packed with 13.9 g of catalyst, which was dehydrated in N2 stream at 150 °C for 2 h, and then sulfided at 315 °C by dimethyl-disulfide diluted in a straight run naphtha stream to reach the sulfide phase. Hydrogen was delivered to the system through a calibrated thermal mass flow-meter, and high pressure diaphragm feed pumps were used for feeding the coker naphtha into the unit from weighed tanks. Prior to testing the catalytic activity, the catalysts were crushed and sieved using a 60 mesh. The HDS and HDN percentages were evaluated using Eq. (1), where Cfeed represents the concentration of sulfur or nitrogen in the feed and Cproduct corresponds to the concentration measured in the product: (1) H D N o r H D S ( % ) = C f e e d - C p r o d u c t C f e e d * 100 2.3 Physicochemical characterizations 2.3.1 Catalysts 29Si MAS NMR spectra were obtained at 79.492 MHz with spinning zirconia rotors, 7 mm of internal diameter, at 5 kHz. Pulses (90°) with 20-s intervals were used. The number of transients was 1004. Silicon chemical shifts were measured with respect to tetramethylsilane (TMS) used as an external reference. All the spectra were acquired on a Bruker 400 spectrometer. The cross-polarization (CP) contact time used in this study was 5 ms, which has been proven to be long enough to permit full cross polarization for silicons to which hydroxyl groups are directly attached. The textural properties of the solids by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at −196 °C were measured with a Quantachrome Automated Gas Sorption System. The samples were previously outgassed under vacuum (0.13 Pa) at 300 °C for 18 h. The pore size distribution was calculated from the adsorption branch according to the BJH method. The concentration of Si in the solids was elicited with an atomic absorption spectrophotometer Perkin Elmer AA 3000. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) was performed by using a Nicolet model 8700 FTIR instrument. The samples diluted in KBr were placed in a cup inside a diffuse reflectance unit. The spectra were averaged over 50 scans in the 400−4000 cm−1 range to a nominal 4 cm−1 resolution. Prior to any experiment, the samples were outgassed at 400 °C under vacuum (1 × 10-4 Pa). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was used in this work for high magnification imaging and elemental chemical analysis. Pellets of fresh and aged catalysts were cut radially to generate a flat surface. The silicon profile was obtained by local chemical analysis through flat surface from the surface to the interior of the pellet. An environmental scanning electron microscope PHILIPS XL30 equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrometer EDAX was used for the analysis. The accelerating voltage in the measurements was 25 kV, and the instrument resolution was 5 nm (30 kV). 2.3.2 HDT feed and products The samples were subjected to chemical characterization following the ASTM 6623-01 procedure appropriate for gasoline distillates using an Agilent 6890 series chromatographic system. The resulting chromatograms were analyzed by a ChemStation employing the hydrocarbon Expert, version 3 software (GC/PIANO). The S and N contents in the feed and products were analyzed by using an Antek sulfur/nitrogen analyzer. The ASTM D4294-98 and ASTM D4629-08a methods were used for sulfur and nitrogen, respectively. 3 Results and discussion The removal of silicon compounds was carried out at 260 °C on different industrial spent catalyst samples using glycerol at different times on stream. As shown in Fig. 1 , the amount of silicon compounds, analyzed by atomic absorption spectroscopy, diminished as the treatment time increased. Moreover, if the first five points in the plot are taken into account, a linear relationship is evident between the amount of silicon compound and reaction time. This behavior can be interpreted as follows: the silicon compounds that are farther from the alumina surface are somehow more labile to be removed by the alcohol function while the nearby compounds present greater difficulty to be extracted. 3.1 NMR characterization 3.1.1 29Si MAS and CP/MAS NMR To characterize the nature of silicon compounds present on the catalysts, 29Si MAS NMR spectra were obtained for all the samples. The 29Si NMR spectra of the spent and glycerol-treated-industrial-NiMo catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . The spectrum of the spent industrial NiMo catalyst shows an intense signal within the −75 and −120 ppm interval and a less intense one in the −50 and −70 ppm interval, which was expected for a catalyst that worked some years. Kellberg et al. [7], in their study by 29Si MAS and 29Si CP/MAS spectroscopies of a series of coker naphtha HDT catalysts deactivated by deposition of silicon, observed the presence of peaks from −22.4 to −14 ppm, which were assigned to surface Si-atoms bound to two methyl groups (D). In the region from −50 to −70 ppm, two resolved resonances at −54 and −64 ppm were assigned to a surface monoalkyl (T) while in the region from −85 to −120 ppm, three overlapping signals positioned at −108, 100 and −90 ppm were attributed to siloxane, silanol and geminal silanol groups (Q), respectively. The results of the analyzed treated samples show (Fig. 2) a progressive reduction of T and Q signals with the reaction time, which evidences a decrease in the amount of silicon species in the catalysts. It is noteworthy to mention that the T silicon type species were deeply removed in comparison with the Q species. A closer inspection of the spectral region from −75 to −120 ppm for the spent sample clearly reveals the presence of three overlapping signals positioned approximately at chemical shifts of −109, −101 and −90 ppm. These signals are assigned to Si(OSi)4, Si(OSi)3(OX) and Si(OSi)2(OX)2 species, respectively, where X could be H or Al. In the case of treated samples from 2 to 8 h, the same three signals can be observed and additionally, another signal attributed to Si(OSi)(OX)3 species was identified at −85 ppm. Finally, for the Re-12 h sample, the Si(OSi)4 peak disappeared while Si(OSi)3(OX), Si(OSi)2(OX)2 and Si(OSi)(OX)3 signals are still present and Si(OX)4 appeared at -80 ppm. For the spent sample, the silicon species presented a condensation degree that was higher than that shown by the treated samples, which indicates that more condensed species are probably the most external and the first to react. As the reaction progresses, less condensed species are formed. Table 1 summarizes the deconvolution results of the 29Si NMR spectra in Gaussians for the spent and treated catalysts. From the deconvolution of 29Si MAS NMR spectra, the progressive decrease in the Si(OSi)4 and Si(OSi)3(OX) signals was detected with the associated increase in the Si(OSi)2(OX)2 and Si(OSi)(OX)3 signals, except for the Re-12 h sample. The decrease in Si(OSi)4 and Si(OSi)3(OX) species could be understood by the depolymerization process, where the reaction proceeds through the opening of the siloxane bridges while the protonated alcohol function involved in the proton exchange process originates the formation of OH groups, which would explain the increase in the Si(OSi)2(OX)2 and Si(OSi)(OX)3 groups [12]. Since the CP process discriminates against 29Si nuclei far away from protons, this technique is a thoughtful method for identifying SiOH groups; it is important to note that this analysis is not affected by the presence of water molecules; then, the preparation of a completely anhydrous sample is not required [13]. In order to obtain more information about the environment of silicon species present in the samples, 29Si CP/MAS NMR experiments were performed. From Fig. 3 , a slight intensity difference among signals was detected with respect to direct polarization (Fig. 2). It is worth noting that because of the difference in CP dynamics for the different silicon species, from this experiment, it is not possible to draw quantitative information, nevertheless, from these experiments, the difference between the signals, which is caused by Si, can be established due to the fact of having close protons from the 4Q signals whose protons are farther and then display a reduced CP rate. Therefore, it is possible to confirm that SiOH groups are attached to silicon. The comparison between 29Si CP/MAS and 29Si MAS spectra was useful to confirm the observation regarding the assignment of different silicon species. The peaks from −104 to −101, from −95 to −90, from −87 to −83 and at −80 ppm are attributed mainly to silicon atoms that have attached hydroxyl groups while the Si(OSi)4 signal is possible to be cross polarized by nearby protons. Therefore, it is evidenced that peaks between 0 and −70 ppm are attributed to CHX and OH attached to silicon. Moreover, Fig. 2 indicates a displacement of the band toward low field as the reaction progresses. In order to prove that depolymerization process (the assignments of the spectral components shown in Table 2 should be applied), the analysis of the solvent (of the sample Re-12 h) used to depolymerize and extract silica was carried out, finding that the methoxylated silica contained in the residues and organic constituents are closely related to those observed in the treated solid. Indeed, the NMR spectra of the solubilized species (Fig. 4 ) feature, with much better resolution, the same characteristics as those shown in the spectra in Fig. 2. The resolution increase is of course linked to the increased mobility. The similarity of the structure and composition of the soluble and insoluble species is an evidence of the suggested depolymerization mechanism. Furthermore, in the solvent, the absolute amount of SiOC is expected to be high (according to Equation 1), and the downfield could be explained by the presence of this kind of species. 3.1.2 27Al MAS NMR 27Al MAS NMR is one of the primary tools in the structural characterization of a variety of alumina-based catalysts. The 27Al MAS NMR spectra of the spent, Re-6 h and Re-12 h catalysts are depicted in Fig. 5 . In agreement with other research works [14,15], the main signal in the spectra lies at about 6−7 ppm, which has been unambiguously assigned to alumina atoms with octahedral coordination. Furthermore, a weaker signal at about 65 ppm is attributed to tetrahedrally-coordinated aluminum. The spectra and intensities of the spent, Re-6 h and Re-12 h samples are quite comparable. Indeed, all the spectra are similar to that of γ–alumina [16]. These findings clearly suggest that the treatment with glycerol does not change the aluminum coordination. One may thus conclude that alumina is not affected by the silica removal with glycerol. 3.2 FTIR analysis IR spectra were carried out on all the samples with the objective of revealing the evolution of the interaction between the alumina and silicon compounds when the last ones are removed from the catalyst surface. In Fig. 6 , the fresh catalyst presents the typical absorption of a transitional alumina in the 1000−400 cm−1 region; furthermore, the strength of the component near 850 cm−1 and the absence of a sharp component supports the identification of this sample as being principally constituted by γ-Al2O3 [17]. On the other hand, the representative IR spectra of the spent catalyst and the treated samples (Fig. 6) show an additional broad absorption, where a stronger or weaker pronounced shoulder in the 1300−800 cm−1 region is evident. The 1300−400 cm−1 region is known to appear only with vibrations related to AlO and SiO [7]. In the 1000−400 cm−1 region, a typical absorption band attributed to a transitional alumina [17,18] was distinguished in all the samples. It is important to note that in this broad composed band, two regions are observed: the first one at 900−650 cm−1 and the second one at 760−400 cm−1, which correspond to tetrahedral and octahedral aluminum, respectively [19]. Finally, it is generally agreed [20] that the SiO stretching (asymmetric) in the silica tetrahedral mode occurs in the 1100−800 cm−1 region. Concerning the spent catalyst, the broad adsorption band in the 1300−980 cm−1 region is clearly composed by a strong signal at ∼1063 cm−1 with a shoulder centered at ∼1145 cm−1. The band in the 1150−1000 cm−1 region is neatly associated with the SiO stretching that is present in this region in all silicate species [21]. It is noteworthy to mention that a sharp and strong component at 801 cm−1 and a shoulder at ∼460 cm−1 emerged in the alumina region; these signals were assigned to a SiOSi symmetric bond stretching vibration network and the second signal was associated with a SiOSi bond bending vibration network [22,23]. Samples treated at different times with glycerol were analyzed and presented comparable spectra as observed in the spent catalyst, however, the intensity of vibration bands associated with SiO diminished. The broad band in the 1300−980 cm−1 region and the component at 801 cm−1 decreased gradually with the time of treatment in glycerol, nevertheless, this last vibration almost disappeared after 12 h while the shoulder at 460 cm−1 disappeared after only 4 h in glycerol. Therefore, the intensity of the 1300−980 cm−1 broad band was directly related to the silicon content in the samples. Based on data reported in the literature and the obtained NMR and IR results, it can be proposed that the bands in the interval ranging from 970 to 1250 cm−1 should be attributed to SiO vibrations associated with n Q sites and the shift at higher vibrational frequencies with the lowest NMR field. According to the results, the silicon compounds covering the alumina surface were gradually removed since the intensity of the band within the 1300−980 cm−1 region diminished with the time of treatment while the distortion of the alumina band in the 1000−400 cm−1 region vanished, confirming that the alumina was restored as the silicon compounds were removed. 3.3 Textural properties The effect of silicon removal on the textural properties was followed. In Fig. 7 , the surface area and pore volume were plotted as a function of silicon content in the catalysts. The spent catalyst, with 8.8 wt. % (determined by atomic absorption spectroscopy), accounted for 100 % of total content while the fresh catalyst accounted for 0 %. As it can be seen, the spent catalyst, which had the highest silicon content, presented the lowest surface area while the fresh catalyst exhibited the highest surface area due to the absence of silicon and carbon compounds. Moreover, as the amount of silicon compounds was removed, an increase in the surface area and pore volume was detected. Therefore, the treatment of spent catalyst with glycerol at different times resulted in the progressive deblockage of pores. It is important to note that the carbon content was measured on the samples and for the spent catalyst, it reached 8.7 wt.% while for the treated samples, the content presented only slight variations oscillating randomly between 8.1 and 8.9 wt.%, which could be explained by the fact that the depolymerization process did not modify significantly the carbon content at the end of the treatment. According to the aforesaid, it could be assumed that the deblocking of pores is only attributed to the removal of silicon compounds, where the higher the removal of silicon compounds, the higher the increase in the surface area and pore volume. 3.4 SEM/EDS study The composition profile was measured on flat surfaces of pellets cut radially. Figs. 8 and 9 show the content of the different elements from the border to the center of the pellets. In the spent catalyst (Fig. 8), the measured silicon concentration was almost constant except on the border, where a high concentration of contaminants was expected to be found. It is important to note that the silicon concentration is quite similar to that of molybdenum. On the other hand, the Re-6 h sample (Fig. 9) exhibited a lower silicon concentration than that of the spent sample; it should be noted that the content of silicon throughout the pellet from the center to the border, was decreasing. The resistance of glycerol to arrive until the center of particle suggests that the removal reaction is diffusional limited. Concerning the other elements, their concentration remained constant except for calcium, which was a contaminant. These results confirm that only the silicon concentration was affected by the treatment with glycerol, which resulted in a selective treatment for silicon compounds. 3.5 Hydrodesulfurization (HDS), hydrodenitrogenation (HDN) and silicon retention activity In order to examine the effect of silicon removal on the catalytic activity, the spent, Re-8 h and Re-12 h samples were evaluated in HDS and HDN using coker naphtha (Table 3 ). The evaluation was carried out at 260 °C in order to evidence the differences regarding the catalytic activity. Samples were taken after 144 h on stream. It is important to mention that samples having different sizes were evaluated to identify the particle size, where the internal diffusion effects can be dismissed. According to Fig. 10 , this point could be reached when the mesh is greater than 50 (dp =0.20 mm). The spent catalyst presented the lowest catalytic activity with 47 % of HDS and 24 % of HDN while Re-8 h exhibited 78 % of HDS and 45 % of HDN and for the Re-12 h sample, the obtained HDS and HDN were 80 and 53 %, respectively. As expected: the higher the silicon removal, the higher the hydrotreatment activity. It is noteworthy that the increase achieved in the HDS activity is higher than that of HDN. It has long been recognized that in HDN, the elimination of nitrogen requires, firstly, the hydrogenation followed by hydrogenolysis [24–26] while the removal of sulfur happens through a hydrogenolysis pathway or hydrogenation followed by hydrogenolysis; hence, HDN is a more difficult reaction than HDS. The restoration of the HDT activity is produced by the elimination of silicon compounds that cause pore blockage with the concomitant uncovering of active sites. Moreover, it is widely assumed that Sicontamination affects significantly the HDN activity while that of HDS is less modified [2,27]. The results demonstrated that the increase in HDN activity was more significant than that in HDS activity. Concerning the silicon retention, the results showed that the spent catalyst retained the 21 % of the silicon compounds contained in the feedstock; once 60 % of silicon species were removed from the spent catalyst by employing the glycerol treatment, it recovered its capacity to trap all the silicon species contained in the feedstock. 4 Conclusion Silicon compounds, that poison the hydrotreating catalysts, were selectively removed with glycerol at 250 °C. Silicon removal increased with the reaction time. As the EDS results showed, the other metals contained in the catalyst remained intact. FTIR and 27Al MAS NMR revealed that the glycerol treatment did not affect the alumina structure; on the other hand, it contributed to its restoration. Structural information obtained by 29Si MAS NMR showed that silicon compounds found in the spent catalyst are mainly of the nQ type. The treatment started by removing 4Q and 3Q species with the increase in 2Q and 1Q species. This fact suggests that more condensed Si species found on the surface are extracted by the glycerol treatment before those bound to Al atoms. In other words, the presence of Al stabilizes neighboring Si atoms and it seems less prone to be extracted. After silicon removal, the silicon retention capacity and HDS and HDN activity were recovered. HDN is more favored with the decreasing silicon content in the catalyst. This research work opens up the possibility of reusing industrial catalysts contaminated with silicon compounds, preventing them from being sent to final disposal after only one use. coredata.dc:description: During hydrotreating, silica poisoning of catalysts represents a severe problem, because the silicone compounds that are present in coker naphtha feedstocks are adsorbed and transformed on the alumina surface, deactivating it. To provide a solution, in the present work, silica was selectively removed from an industrial Ni-Mo/Al2O3 spent catalyst by applying a depolymerization process with glycerol that resulted in the restoration of silicon retention capacity, hydrodesulfurization and hydrodenitrogenation activities and physical properties of the catalyst. Catalyst samples, before and after the removal of silica compounds, were studied by nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR), N2 physisorption, diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS), atomic absorption spectroscopy and scanning electron microscopy (SEM).
coredata.dc:title: Novel solution for removing poisonous silica from a Ni-Mo/Al2O3 industrial HDT spent catalyst
